title: Why does a vacuum not exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: The popular notion of a vacuum is the absence of air, which is still correct or astronauts would not carry breathing equipment. We also now know that fluids like air are not actually continuous, but are composed of very rapidly moving tiny particles called molecules. They collide randomly like balls in a pinball machine, and so manage to effectively occupy a volume in a time frame much shorter than you can blink your eye. If you think about it, they must be moving supersonic and colluding at very high rates, or they wouldn't be able to support sound waves. So there are no molecules between molecules but only over very short time frames. Physics has decided that it is seething with stuff, other than air molecules. So it very much does exist. Now, in fact if you supply enough energy the vacuum itself becomes very active and can pop out new particles. Yes, you heard me, creation of new particles, so creation of matter is not something you relegate should to the past, it is ever present in the universe. So not only does it exist, it is involved in the existence of matter. Your question can be looked at another way, why is all the air not spread everywhere equally? The answer to that is gravity, it holds the air to earth. Also the universe has greatly expanded so much that the hot dense material that once filled it has become very thin, both the pressure and temperature have plummeted.
